Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Respect the mentor's time and availability.
Situation2: The mentor arranged a short meeting in an otherwise packed day.
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my older sister: “Don’t forget, dinner at 7! Can’t wait to celebrate your new job!” I smiled, feeling a warm sense of pride. She’d always been there for me, and tonight was my turn to show up for her, to laugh and share stories over her favorite pasta. But just as I was about to leave, my mentor emailed: “I have 30 minutes free at 7 PM. Let’s discuss your project then—I won’t have time again this week.” My heart sank. I knew how rare it was for her to carve out time, and I owed so much of my progress to her guidance. I stared at my phone, torn. My sister expected me to be present, to celebrate together as family. My mentor expected me to seize this rare opportunity, to show commitment and respect for her time. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt caught between two worlds, each pulling me in a different direction.
